tn.text: Paul is on trial in Caesarea. Tertullus presents Governor Felix with the charges against Paul.
Here the word "you" refers to Felix, the governor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "we" refers to the citizens under Felix. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
"five days after the Roman soldiers took Paul to Caesarea"

This is the name of a man. This is not the same Ananias as in [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:01|5:1]] nor the same Ananias as in [[:en:bible:notes:act:09:10|9:10]]. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:23:01|23:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"a lawyer." Tertullus was an expert in Roman law who was there to accuse Paul in court.
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"went to Caesarea where Paul was"
"in the presence of the governor who was judge in the court"
"began to bring violations of law against him" governor.
Here "we" refers to the citizens under Felix. AT: "we, the people that you govern, have great peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: and your foresight brings good reform to our nation
tn.text: "and your planning has greatly improved our nation"
"Governor Felix who deserves greatest honor" Felix was the roman governor over the whole region. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:act:23:25|23:25]].
The word "we" refers to Ananias, certain elders, and Tertullus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: So that I detain you no more
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "so that I will not take up too much of your time" (UDB) or 2) "so that I will not tire you"

tn.ref: briefly listen to me with kindness
tn.text: "kindly listen to my short speech"

tn.ref: this man to be a pest
tn.text: This speaks of Paul as if he were a plague that spreads from one person to another. AT: "this man to be a trouble maker" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: all the Jews throughout the world
tn.text: The word "all" here is used to exaggerate the accusation against Paul. AT: "many Jews throughout the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: He is a leader of the Nazarene sect
tn.text: The phrase "Nazarene sect" is another name for the Christians. AT: "He also leads the entire group whom people call the followers of the Nazarene" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is a smaller group of people within a larger group group. Tertullus considers the Christians to be a small group within Judaism.
Tertullus finishes presenting the charges against Paul before Governor Felix.
Here the word "you" is singular and refers to Governor Felix. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"accuse Paul of doing" or "accuse Paul of being guilty of doing"
This refers to the Jewish leaders who were there at Paul's trial. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Paul responds to Governor Felix about the charges brought against him.
Here the word "they" refers to the Jews who were accusing Paul.
"the governor gestured"
Here "nation" refers to the people of the Jewish nation. AT: "a judge for the people of the Jewish nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"explain my situation"
"You will be able to prove"
"12 days since" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: I did not stir up a crowd
tn.text: "Stir up" is a metaphor for agitating people into unrest, just as stirring a liquid agitates it. AT: "I did not provoke the crowd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the blames for wrongdoings" or "the charges for crimes"
"I acknowledge this to you" or "I confess this to you"
The phrase "the way" was a title used for Christianity during Paul's time.

This is a smaller group of people within a larger group group. Tertullus considers the Christians to be a small group within Judaism. See how you translated "sect" in [[:en:bible:notes:act:24:04|24:5]].

tn.ref: in that same way I serve the God of our forefathers
tn.text: Paul uses the phrase "in that same way" to mean that he, as a believer in Jesus, serves God the same way as the Jewish forefathers did. He is not leading a "sect" or teaching something new that is opposed to their ancient religion.
Here "these men" refers to the Jews who are accusing Paul in court.

tn.ref: the coming resurrection of ... unrighteous ones
tn.text: The abstract noun "resurrection" can be stated as "God brings back to life." The nominal adjective "the dead" can be stated as "those who died." AT: "when God brings back to life all who have died, both the righteous and the unrighteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"those who have done what is right"
"those who have done what is evil"
"I do my best"

tn.ref: to have a conscience without blame
tn.text: Here "conscience" refers to a person's inner morality that chooses between right and wrong. AT: "to be blameless" or "to always do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"in the presence of God"
This word marks a shift in Paul's argument. Here he explains the situation in Jerusalem when some of the Jews arrested him.
"after many years away from Jerusalem"

tn.ref: I came to bring help to my nation and gifts of money
tn.text: Here "I came" can be translated as "I went." AT: "I went to help my people by bringing them money as a gift" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])

tn.ref: in a purification ceremony in the temple
tn.text: "in the temple after I had finished a ceremony to purify myself"

tn.ref: not with a crowd or an uproar
tn.text: This can be stated as a separate new sentence. AT: "I had not gathered a crowd nor was I trying to start a riot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"The Jews from Asia"
"if they have anything to say"
Paul finishes responding to Governor Felix about the charges brought against him.
This refers to the members of the council who were present in Jerusalem at Paul's trial.

tn.ref: should say what wrong they found in me
tn.text: "should say the wrong thing I did that they were able to prove"

tn.ref: It is about the resurrection of the dead
tn.text: The abstract noun "resurrection" can be stated as "God brings back to life." The nominal adjective "dead" can be stated as "those who died." AT: "It is because I believe that God will bring back to life those who have died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: I am being judged today by you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "you are judging me today" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Felix is the Roman governor of the area who resides at Caesarea. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:act:23:22|23:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is a title for Christianity. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:09:01|9:2]].

tn.ref: Whenever Lysias the commander comes down
tn.text: "when Lysias the commander comes down" or "at the time Lysias the commander comes down"
This is the name of the chief captain. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:act:23:25|23:26]].
Jerusalem was higher than Caesarea so it was normal for them to speak of coming down from Jerusalem.
"I will make a decision concerning these accusations against you" or "I will judge whether you are guilty"
"grant Paul some freedom not otherwise granted to prisoners"
"After several days"
Druscilla is a woman's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This means a female Jew. AT: "who was a Jew" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Felix may have felt conviction of his sins.
"for the present time"

tn.ref: Paul would give money to him
tn.text: Felix was hoping Paul would offer him a bribe to set him free.

tn.ref: so he often sent for him and spoke with him
tn.text: "so Felix often sent for Paul and spoke with Paul"
This was the new roman Governor who replaced Felix. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: wanted to gain favor with the Jews
tn.text: Here "the Jews" refers to the Jewish leaders. AT: "wanted the Jewish leaders to like him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: he left Paul to continue under guard
tn.text: "he left Paul in prison"
